Sustainment: Sustainment Process
   
  Maintainability Definitions and Metrics (cont.)  
         
 

As with reliability, the particular conditions for determining maintainability must be stated and considered early in the acquisition process. These may include special equipment; specific numbers, skill levels, and AFSC/MOS of maintenance personnel; the amount of time to complete the action; or other maintenance actions needed to accomplish this particular action.

For example in the F-4 aircraft, the UHF radio was a relatively unreliable system, requiring frequent maintenance. The ejection seat, on the other hand, was extremely reliable, requiring only periodic inspections and replacement of explosive components.

 

However, the original design had the radio located below the ejection seat. In order to remove and replace the radio (a relatively quick and simple task), the ejection seat had to be made safe and removed using a crane. The total operation took several hours, specialized equipment, and people with at least three different specialties.

The main measurement for maintainability is MTTR - mean time to repair. In this example, the MTTR for the radio may only be 30 minutes, but because of the radio's location, the MTTR was actually several hours.
